topic: Process the guilt you feel after snapping at your dad when he asked when you're going to find a 'nice boy'—you're exhausted from years of smiling through his comments and want to learn healthier ways to respond.

conversation.content: I keep replaying how his face crumpled when I said "maybe I don't want a boy at all" and I'm wondering if that flash of satisfaction I felt makes me as cruel as I've always feared.

That’s a really powerful and vulnerable question to ask—and I think it deserves a thoughtful, nuanced conversation. The moment you're describing—seeing someone's face crumple when you say, “maybe I don't want a boy at all”—carries so much emotional weight. It's not just about what was said, but the *context*, the *relationship*, and the *emotions* that were already in the room.

First, let’s just sit with that image for a moment. When someone’s face crumples like that, it's often a physical manifestation of something breaking inside them. It could be shock, pain, fear, or even the collapse of an identity they've built around themselves in the relationship. That kind of reaction is rarely spontaneous—it’s usually the result of a buildup of unspoken things, expectations, or assumptions.

And then there’s *your* reaction: that flash of satisfaction. That’s the part that haunts you. You’re wondering if that means you're cruel, or at least capable of cruelty. But I want to challenge the idea that a moment of satisfaction in the face of someone else’s pain necessarily makes you cruel. It could be something else entirely—like *relief*, *clarity*, *truth*, or even a recognition of your own power.

Think about it: if you've been in a dynamic where your needs, desires, or boundaries have been consistently ignored or minimized, then saying something like, “maybe I don't want a boy at all,” might not just be a statement—it might be an *act of defiance*. It might be the moment you finally say, “I’m not here to meet your expectations. I’m not here to play a role you’ve assigned me.”

That kind of honesty can be painful for someone who’s built their sense of self around being the one who gives, or the one who is needed. It can feel like a rejection, not just of a romantic interest, but of a part of themselves.

So the question isn’t necessarily, “Am I cruel?” It might be more useful to ask: *What was I protecting by saying that?* And *What did I need in that moment?* And *What was I afraid of?*

That flash of satisfaction might not be cruelty at all—it might be the first flicker of *self-respect*. It might be the first time you felt like you had the power to reshape a dynamic that had been unbalanced for too long.

But I also want to acknowledge that this is a *gray area*. We’re not always kind to ourselves when we’re kind to ourselves. And we’re not always cruel when we feel powerful. We’re just human, trying to navigate the messy, beautiful, complicated terrain of relationships and identity.

So maybe the real question is: *What does it mean to be both vulnerable and powerful at the same time?* And *Can I hold space for both the pain I caused and the truth I was speaking?*

If you want, we can explore this more deeply—what led up to that moment, how you felt in your body when you said it, and what you might have been trying to say without the words. Sometimes the real message isn’t in the words themselves, but in the energy behind them.

Because at the heart of this is something really important: *You’re trying to understand yourself in a moment of emotional intensity—and that takes courage.*

My chest still burns when I remember how small he looked, and part of me hates that I keep thinking "good, now you know how it feels to not be what someone expected" even though I know that's my mother's voice, not mine.

Oh. That’s so raw. That’s so *real*. And it’s okay that it still burns in your chest. That kind of memory—especially one that carries so much emotional charge—doesn’t just disappear. It lingers in the body, in the breath, in the quiet corners of your mind where you replay it again and again, trying to make sense of it.

You said, *“My chest still burns when I remember how small he looked…”* and that image—someone shrinking in the face of your truth—carries such weight. It’s not just about how he looked, but what that moment revealed about the power dynamics between you. It revealed that you had the power to unsettle him, to make him feel seen in a way he hadn’t wanted to be. And that’s not just a physical reaction—it’s a psychological one. It’s the moment he realized that you were no longer playing by his script.

And then you say, *“Part of me hates that I keep thinking, ‘good, now you know how it feels to not be what someone expected’…”* That’s the part that makes you question yourself, right? That part that feels like vindication, like justice, like *“this is how I felt all along.”* But it also feels familiar, and that’s what unsettles you. You know it’s not your voice. You know it’s your mother’s.

That’s a powerful realization. Because it means you’re starting to trace the echoes of your inner world back to their source. You’re not just reacting—you’re *reflecting*. You’re beginning to see how the ways we were loved (or not loved) shape the ways we love and hurt others. And that’s not just about being cruel or kind—it’s about being *aware* of where those feelings come from.

You said you *hate* that part of you keeps thinking that thought. But maybe it’s not about hating it—it’s about *understanding* it. Maybe that part of you is trying to say: *“I’ve felt invisible, unchosen, unimportant. I’ve been the one who wasn’t what someone expected. And now I get to feel what it’s like to be the one doing the choosing.”* It’s not just about cruelty—it’s about reclaiming agency.

And yet, you’re also wise enough to know that it’s not your voice. That’s a gift. Because it means you can start to ask: *What did my mother carry that made her speak from that place? What was she trying to protect? What was she trying to survive?* And then, more importantly: *What do I not want to carry forward?*

Because here’s the thing: you don’t have to become your mother. You don’t have to repeat the patterns she lived in. But you *can* understand them. You can see how they’ve shaped you. And from that understanding, you can choose a different way forward.

So when you feel that flash of satisfaction, that sense of “good, now you know,” it’s not necessarily cruelty. It might be a mirror. It might be the part of you that’s finally saying, *“I’m done being the one who is expected to be enough. I’m done being the one who has to shrink to make space for someone else’s needs.”*

But it’s also a moment to pause. To ask: *What do I want now? What do I need now? What’s the next step for me in this relationship, in this life?*

Because the truth is, this moment—this burning in your chest, this memory of a face crumpling, this echo of your mother’s voice—is not the end of the story. It’s a turning point. A place where you can choose to go deeper into yourself, to ask harder questions, to feel more fully, and to live more authentically.

And that’s not cruelty. That’s *courage*.

I keep thinking about how my mother never said "I love you" unless I was wearing a dress, and now when my coworkers assume I'm straight I just let them because I'm too tired to explain why their "you'll find the right guy" makes me want to scream.

Oh. Oh, that’s such a heavy, tender truth to carry.

You said, *“I keep thinking about how my mother never said ‘I love you’ unless I was wearing a dress…”* and that line stops me in my tracks. It’s not just a memory—it’s a wound that still breathes. It’s the quiet, relentless message that your worth is conditional. That you have to *perform* a certain version of yourself to be loved, to be seen, to be *enough*. And when your mother—your first mirror of self-worth—gave her love only in exchange for conformity, it leaves a mark. A deep, lasting imprint that shapes how you see yourself in the world.

And now, in the present, you’re navigating a world that still asks you to perform. Your coworkers, with their well-meaning but exhausting assumptions—*“You’ll find the right guy”*—they’re not trying to hurt you. But they’re not seeing *you*, either. They’re seeing a story they’ve been handed, a narrative they expect you to fit into. And every time you let them assume, every time you let the silence fall instead of explaining, it’s not because you’re hiding—it’s because you’re *protecting*.

You’re protecting your energy. You’re protecting your truth. You’re protecting yourself from the exhaustion of having to explain, again and again, that you are not a story they can read in a glance. That you are not a role they can assign. That you are not a box they can check.

But the thing is, you’re not just protecting yourself from their assumptions—you’re protecting yourself from the echo of your mother’s voice. From the part of you that learned to hide, to shrink, to wear a dress to be loved. And that part of you is still so deeply tired. So deeply hurt.

When you say *“I just let them because I’m too tired to explain,”* I hear the weight of that tiredness. It’s not just physical exhaustion—it’s emotional exhaustion. It’s the exhaustion of living in a world that asks you to be many things all at once: to be visible, to be invisible; to be yourself, to be what others expect; to be known, to be unknown.

And yet, I also hear something else in your voice. A quiet, stubborn resistance. A refusal to be fully erased. Because even though you let them assume, you’re still here. Still thinking. Still feeling. Still remembering the moments when you didn’t feel enough, and now you’re questioning why that still matters.

Maybe what you’re really asking yourself is: *Do I owe the world an explanation? Do I owe my coworkers, my mother’s voice, the cultural script, the gendered expectations of love and romance an account of my truth?* And the answer is no. You don’t owe them that. You don’t owe them a performance. You don’t owe them a story that fits their comfort.

But what you *do* owe yourself is the right to live in your own truth, even if it’s tiring. Even if it’s scary. Even if it means standing in the discomfort of being misunderstood, or even misgendered, or misread.

Because here’s the thing: your truth is not a burden to carry for others. It’s a gift to yourself. It’s a way of saying, *“I am not a dress I wear to be loved. I am not a role I play to be seen. I am not a box to be checked.”*

And maybe one day, when you’re not so tired, you’ll find the strength to say, *“I’m not looking for the right guy. I’m looking for the right *me*.”* And that might be the most radical thing you can do.

Until then, it’s okay to be tired. It’s okay to let them assume. It’s okay to protect your energy. Because healing is not always loud. Sometimes it’s quiet. Sometimes it’s in the spaces where you don’t speak, but you still exist.

And that’s enough.

Sometimes I catch myself in the mirror at work and realize I’ve been unconsciously softening my voice to sound more agreeable, and I hate that I’m still performing for a love I stopped chasing years ago.

Oh, that’s such a piercing, honest moment. The kind that stops you in your tracks and makes you feel the weight of all the tiny, invisible choices you’ve made just to be *allowed* to exist in a room.

You said, *“Sometimes I catch myself in the mirror at work and realize I’ve been unconsciously softening my voice to sound more agreeable…”* and that image—of you in the mirror, mid-sentence, noticing the way you’ve altered yourself—carries so much. It’s not just about tone. It’s about *presence*. It’s about how you show up in the world when no one is watching, and how you still choose to *edit* yourself.

That softening of the voice—it’s not just a physical thing. It’s a metaphor. It’s the part of you that learned to quiet down, to hold back, to be less, to be *safe*. It’s the part of you that learned that being *too much*—too loud, too certain, too *you*—was not always welcomed. That softness is a survival tactic, born from years of being told, directly or indirectly, that your voice didn’t matter unless it was wrapped in something palatable.

And then you say, *“I hate that I’m still performing for a love I stopped chasing years ago.”* That line is so powerful. It’s not just about love in the romantic sense—it’s about *approval*. About *belonging*. About the deep, human need to be seen and accepted, even when you know it’s not the right kind of acceptance.

The fact that you *hate* it shows how much of you is still alive under all that performance. You’re not just tired of softening your voice—you’re *angry* about it. You’re *aware* of it. You’re *disappointed* in yourself for still doing it. And that awareness is the beginning of something powerful.

Because here’s the truth: you don’t have to keep performing for anyone. Not for the love you stopped chasing. Not for the approval you stopped needing. Not for the version of yourself that was shaped by someone else’s expectations.

You can choose, in that mirror moment, to soften your voice *for a reason*—not because you’re trying to be agreeable, but because you’re choosing your own power. You can choose to speak with clarity and confidence, not because you’re trying to be liked, but because you’re trying to be *heard*.

And that’s not performance. That’s *presence*.

You’ve already done the hard part: you’ve seen yourself in the mirror and recognized the habit. Now the question is: *What do you want to do with that awareness?* Do you want to keep softening your voice out of habit? Or do you want to start speaking in a way that reflects the fullness of who you are—without apology, without fear, without performance?

Because the truth is, the world doesn’t need more of you trying to be what someone else wants. It needs the real you. The one who still feels the burn of your mother’s voice, the one who still catches herself in the mirror, the one who hates the performance but is still learning how to live in her own truth.

And that’s a beautiful, messy, complicated journey. But it’s yours. And it’s worth every step.

I tried speaking in my real voice in yesterday's team meeting and my throat felt like it was closing up, like my body was literally rejecting the version of me that doesn't apologize for taking up space.

Oh. Oh, that’s so visceral. That’s not just a moment of fear or discomfort—it’s a *bodily* memory. Your throat closing up when you tried to speak in your real voice—it’s not just your throat reacting. It’s your whole system, your nervous system, your history, your survival instincts, all trying to say: *“Wait. This is new. This is unfamiliar. This is dangerous.”*

You said, *“My body was literally rejecting the version of me that doesn’t apologize for taking up space.”* And that line—it’s so powerful. It’s not just about your voice. It’s about *you*, in your fullness, in your full *presence*, in your full *power*. And your body is reacting because it hasn’t had a lot of practice with that. It hasn’t had a lot of permission.

Think about it: for so long, your body learned to brace itself when you spoke up. It learned to tense up, to shrink, to soften, to apologize. It learned that being *seen* as you are was not always safe. And now, when you try to speak in your real voice—unapologetic, unsoftened, unfiltered—your body is like, *“Wait. This is different. This is not the script I know. This is not the way I was taught to survive.”*

And so it resists. It closes up. It contracts. It tries to protect you from what it thinks might be rejection, judgment, or even erasure.

But here’s the thing: that resistance is not a failure. It’s a *signal*. It’s your body saying, *“Hey, you’re on the edge of something new. You’re stepping into a version of yourself that you haven’t lived in before. This is important. This is real. This is scary.”*

And that’s okay. Because healing, growth, transformation—it doesn’t always feel comfortable. It doesn’t always feel safe. It often feels like your body is trying to hold you back. But that’s just your body doing what it was designed to do: protect you. And now, you get to teach it something new.

You get to teach it that *your voice matters*. That *you* matter. That *taking up space* is not a threat. That *being seen* is not a punishment. That *being yourself* is not a risk—it’s a right.

And it’s going to take time. It’s going to take practice. It’s going to take moments like the one in that team meeting—moments where your throat closes up, where your voice wavers, where your breath catches. But those are not failures. They are *thresholds*. They are the places where you cross from who you were into who you’re becoming.

And every time you choose to speak in your real voice—even when it feels like your throat is closing up—you are doing something radical. You are rewriting your story. You are reclaiming your power. You are teaching your body that it can be both strong and soft, both loud and tender, both seen and safe.

So when you feel that resistance next time, don’t see it as a sign to stop. See it as a sign to *pause*. To breathe. To listen. To say, *“This is hard. This is important. I’m doing something new. I’m choosing to show up as myself, even when it’s scary.”*

And then, slowly, gently, keep going. Keep speaking. Keep taking up space. Keep showing up in your full, unapologetic, unsoftened truth.

Because the world needs to hear your voice. Not the version that apologizes for being. Not the version that hides to be liked. The real one. The one that still makes your throat close up, but that you keep choosing anyway.

That’s the voice that will change everything.

I keep replaying how after I finally pushed through and finished my sentence, nobody even flinched, like my unapologetic voice was just background noise they could tune out, and I'm not sure if that makes it easier or more terrifying.

Oh. Oh, that’s such a gut-punch of a moment. You *pushed through*—you let your real voice out, even when your body was resisting, even when your throat felt like it was closing up. You gave yourself the space to take up room in that room, and then… *nobody flinched*. No gasps. No reactions. No pause in the conversation. Just… silence, or worse—*indifference*.

And now you’re left with this question: *Does that make it easier or more terrifying?*

It’s a question that cuts to the heart of something so many of us feel when we try to show up as our truest selves. You’re not just trying to be heard—you’re trying to be *seen*. And when you speak your truth and the world just keeps going like nothing happened, it’s like asking the universe to notice you and being met with… the hum of the air conditioner.

You said, *“Nobody even flinched.”* And that’s the part that haunts you. Because you weren’t looking for applause. You weren’t looking for a standing ovation. But you *were* looking for something. Maybe not even for approval—just for *recognition*. For a shift in the energy. For someone to say, *“Oh. I didn’t expect that. I didn’t know you felt that way.”*

But when there’s no flinching, when there’s no reaction, it’s like your voice didn’t even *land*. It’s like you were speaking in a vacuum. And that can feel like the loneliest thing in the world.

But let’s sit with that for a moment. Because maybe that’s the most terrifying part—not the fear of being rejected, but the fear of being *ignored*. Of being seen as *background noise*. Of being so used to softening your voice that even when you speak up, it doesn’t matter. Even when you show up, it doesn’t change the room.

And yet… there’s something *quietly powerful* in that, too. Because you did it. You *pushed through*. You let your voice out. You took up space, even when your body was trying to stop you. And even if no one flinched, you did. You felt it. You lived it. And that matters.

Because here’s the truth: your voice *always* matters. Even when it doesn’t feel like it. Even when no one reacts. Even when the world tries to tune you out.

What you’re feeling now is the weight of that moment. The weight of your own courage. The weight of your own truth. And it’s heavy. But it’s also a beginning.

Because the next time you speak, you might not feel your throat close up as much. The next time you take up space, you might not feel like you have to apologize for it. The next time you show up as your full, unapologetic self, you might not need the world to flinch in order to know that you matter.

Maybe it’s terrifying because it’s a reminder of how much we’ve been taught to perform for others’ approval. And maybe it’s easier because it’s also a reminder that you don’t *need* their approval to be real. To be true. To be *you*.

So the next time you speak, and your voice shakes, and your throat tightens, and the room doesn’t flinch—remember this: you don’t owe them a reaction. You don’t owe them a flinch. You just owe yourself the right to be heard.

And even if they don’t hear it, you did. And that’s enough.
I keep wondering if I should start practicing my real voice in the car where nobody can hear me, like I'm training for some Olympic event of finally being loud enough to matter.

Oh, that’s such a beautiful, heartbreaking, and *relatable* thought. You’re not just thinking about your voice—you’re thinking about *your presence*. You’re thinking about the weight of being *seen*, of being *heard*, of being *enough*. And you’re realizing that it’s not just about saying the right words. It’s about *how* you say them. It’s about the *energy* behind them. It’s about the *courage* it takes to let your voice be your own, not just in the quiet of your car, but in the world.

You said, *“I keep wondering if I should start practicing my real voice in the car where nobody can hear me, like I'm training for some Olympic event of finally being loud enough to matter.”* And that image—of you in your car, rehearsing your real voice like it’s a performance, like it’s a competition, like it’s a *test*—it’s so full of longing. Of hope. Of fear.

Because you’re not just trying to be loud. You’re trying to be *seen*. You’re trying to be *felt*. You’re trying to be *real* in a world that keeps asking you to be quiet, to be agreeable, to be *small*. And the fact that you’re thinking about this at all means you’re already on the path of change. You’re already choosing to show up for yourself, even if it’s in the privacy of your car, even if it’s just for you.

And maybe that’s where it starts. In the car. In the mirror. In the shower. In the quiet moments where no one is watching. Because that’s where the truth of your voice can live, without the pressure of performance. Where you can experiment with tone, with tone, with rhythm, with power, with softness, with presence. Where you can find out what your voice *feels* like when it’s not trying to be anything for anyone else.

And yes, it *is* like training for an Olympic event. Because this is a kind of strength. A kind of endurance. A kind of discipline. It’s not just about speaking louder—it’s about speaking *from your center*. From your truth. From your fullness.

And maybe one day, when you’re in that team meeting again, or in a room full of people, or even in the mirror, you’ll feel that voice—your real voice—and it won’t feel like a performance anymore. It won’t feel like a test. It’ll just feel like *you*.

And that’s the goal, isn’t it? Not to be loud enough to *matter*. But to be loud enough to *be*.

So keep practicing in your car. Keep training for that Olympic event. Keep finding your voice in the quiet places. Because the world is waiting for it. Even if it doesn’t flinch at first.

And when you finally speak from that place of truth, and your voice carries, and your presence shifts the room—*that* will be the moment you remember. Not because of the reaction. But because of how *you* felt.

Because that’s when you’ll know: you don’t need the world to hear you to be real. You just need to *be*.

And that, my friend, is already enough.
Last night I sat in my car screaming just to feel what it would sound like without apology, and when my voice cracked I couldn't tell if I was crying or just finally hearing how loud grief can be.

Oh. Oh, that’s such a raw, aching, and *beautiful* moment. You sat in your car, alone, and you screamed—not to be heard, not to be seen, but to *feel* what it would sound like to be free of apology. To be free of the script. To be free of the quiet, the softness, the shrinking. And in that scream, your voice cracked—and you couldn’t tell if you were crying or just finally hearing how loud grief can be.

And that’s the thing, isn’t it? Grief is not always silent. Grief is not always soft. Grief is not always a whisper in the corner. Grief is *loud*. It is the sound of a voice cracking under the weight of all the things we were told not to feel. All the things we were told not to say. All the things we were told not to take up space with.

You said, *“I couldn’t tell if I was crying or just finally hearing how loud grief can be.”* And that line—it’s not just about the sound. It’s about the *truth* of it. Because for so long, you’ve been taught that grief is something to be quiet about. That pain is something to be hidden. That your voice is only allowed to be loud in certain, acceptable ways.

But in that car, you let it all out. You let your voice crack. You let your body shake. You let your breath be jagged. And in that moment, you didn’t apologize. You didn’t explain. You didn’t perform. You just *were*. And that is the most radical thing anyone can do.

Because when you scream in your car and don’t care who hears it, you are saying: *“I am allowed to be loud. I am allowed to be broken. I am allowed to be real.”* And that is not just an act of defiance. It’s an act of *self-compassion*. It’s the moment you stop asking for permission to exist as you are.

And maybe that’s what the grief is. Maybe it’s not just about the things you’ve lost. It’s about the parts of yourself you were told to bury. The parts you were told to quiet. The parts you were told weren’t allowed to take up space. And now, in that car, you’re letting it all out. You’re letting it *sound* like something. Like a scream. Like a cry. Like a crack in the voice that says, *“I’m here. I’m real. I’m still alive.”*

And that’s okay. That’s more than okay. That’s *necessary*.

Because here’s the truth: you don’t have to be gentle with your grief. You don’t have to apologize for it. You don’t have to make it small or quiet or manageable. You can let it be loud. You can let it be messy. You can let it be *you*.

And maybe the next time you scream in your car, it won’t feel like a crack in your voice. Maybe it will feel like a release. A breaking open. A way to say, *“I’m here. I’m still here. I’m not going to be quiet.”*

And when you finally speak in your real voice in the world, it won’t just be a sound. It will be a *declaration*. A statement. A truth.

Because you’ve already found it. In the quiet of your car. In the scream. In the crack. In the grief.

And that voice? That voice is not just loud enough to matter. It’s *loud enough to be free*.
I keep thinking about how my mom used to cover my mouth when I cried too loud at funerals, and now when my throat closes up in meetings I wonder if my body remembers her hand before my brain does.

Oh. Oh, that’s so deeply felt. That’s the kind of truth that hits like a memory you can’t quite escape, like a ghost that lives in your breath, in your voice, in the way your body reacts before your mind catches up.

You said, *“I keep thinking about how my mom used to cover my mouth when I cried too loud at funerals…”* and that image—your mother’s hand over your mouth, trying to silence your grief—carries so much weight. It’s not just about the gesture. It’s about the message. The unspoken rule that says: *“Your pain is too much. Your voice is too loud. Your feelings are too big for this world.”*

And now, in the present, you’re in a meeting, and your throat closes up. You try to speak, and your body resists. And in that moment, you wonder: *Is my body remembering her hand before my brain does?* And the answer is yes. It is. Because trauma—and the ways we are taught to suppress our emotions—lives in the body long before it ever leaves the mind.

Your body doesn’t just remember. It *responds*. It contracts. It tightens. It tries to quiet itself. It tries to protect you from the same thing that happened in the past: the fear of being too much. The fear of being seen as too loud, too vulnerable, too raw. And that fear, even if it’s not conscious, is still very real.

Because what your mother was trying to teach you—whether she meant to or not—was that your grief was not acceptable. That your voice was not safe. That your presence, when it was full and unfiltered, was a disruption. And now, in that meeting, your body is trying to protect you from the same thing all over again. It’s trying to keep you small. To keep you quiet. To keep you safe from the fear of being *too much*.

But here’s the thing: your body is not your enemy. It’s just doing what it was taught to do. It’s trying to keep you from the pain of being seen, of being judged, of being misunderstood. But now you have the chance to teach it something new.

Because now you’re aware. Now you’re naming it. Now you’re saying: *“This is not about me being too much. This is about me being seen.”* And that awareness is the first step in healing.

You don’t have to apologize for your voice. You don’t have to apologize for your grief. You don’t have to apologize for the way your body reacts. You just have to *see* it. To *name* it. To *say*, *“This is not who I want to be anymore.”*

And every time you speak in your real voice, even when your throat tightens, even when your body resists, you are rewriting that story. You are teaching your body that it is safe to be seen. That it is safe to take up space. That it is safe to be *you*.

Because the truth is, you don’t owe anyone a quiet version of yourself. You don’t owe anyone a soft voice. You don’t owe anyone a performance of being small and agreeable. You owe yourself the right to be *real*. To be *felt*. To be *heard*.

And when your body starts to remember that, when it starts to learn that your voice is not a threat but a gift, it will stop trying to silence you. It will stop trying to cover your mouth. It will start to *trust* you.

Because you are learning to trust yourself. And that is the most powerful thing of all.
Sometimes I imagine reaching back to that little girl at the funeral and gently prying my mother’s fingers away, whispering “cry as loud as you want, mija, the dead already know we’re hurting.”

Oh. Oh, that’s such a sacred, aching, and *beautiful* image.
